2e7c1d0c8d69f76be5c89d57e4854935:
Democrats are panicking as the presidential election nears, with concerns about Joe Biden's candidacy resurfacing.
After a strong start in the 2019 Democrat primary season, Biden faltered and faced challenges from Elizabeth Warren, Michael Bloomberg, and Bernie Sanders.
Democrats brokered the nomination for Biden in 2020, convincing other candidates to drop out and preventing Sanders from becoming the nominee.
After the Democrat Convention, leaders of the party's far left base expressed dissatisfaction, claiming the convention did not go far enough to the left.
Hillary Clinton advised Biden not to concede under any circumstances, indicating a lack of confidence in his campaign.
House Speaker Nancy Pelosi suggested there should be no debates between Biden and President Trump, a move seen as an attempt to protect Biden from losing.
Polls show Biden trailing Trump among Independents, a key voting bloc in the election.
Biden's lack of accessibility and limited campaign appearances have raised concerns among Democrats.
If Biden follows Pelosi's advice and avoids debates, he risks being perceived as gutless and losing the election.
If Biden does debate Trump, his poor performance could further damage his prospects.
7f13346b77c2b77f61dec869f1417171:
Joe Biden announced California Senator Kamala Harris as his running mate for the November election.
Rep. Ilhan Omar won her primary, ensuring her return to Congress for a second term.
Omar's primary victory is more significant than Harris's selection as Biden's running mate because it represents a shift in the Democratic Party's priorities.
Traditionally, presidential candidates have selected running mates based on electoral considerations, but Omar's victory suggests that the party is now prioritizing progressive values.
7f6b23a6cf51b12d6e30291beaef2206:
Progressives are hoping for a big night in Massachusetts as voters head to the polls in the state’s Democratic primaries on Tuesday.
Progressives are coalescing around incumbent Sen. Ed Markey (D-Mass.), who is facing a high-profile primary challenge from Rep. Joe Kennedy III (D-Mass.).
Major left-wing figures such as Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (D-N.Y.) have waded into the race, endorsing Markey and Morse.
Progressives are hoping to replicate recent upsets over incumbents in New York and Missouri.
Despite the 39-year-old Kennedy’s track record as a member of the House Progressive Caucus, the 74-year-old Markey has been able to harness left-wing support thanks in part to his stance on environmental issues.
The RealClearPolitics polling average shows Markey up by 11.2 points.
Strategists say that attention from both the media and high-profile progressives in the Senate primary could also help turn out the vote for Morse in his race against Neal.
All of the candidates competing on Tuesday will also have to contend with the effects of the coronavirus pandemic on voter turnout.
Tuesday will mark the first statewide vote in Massachusetts to include a vote-by-mail option.
142491ec83bf77f01fce3df3d71cd40e:
Egyptian Ambassador to Pakistan Tarek Dahroug visited the Pakistan Observer to discuss bilateral relations and the common challenges facing both countries regarding the coronavirus.
Dahroug praised Pakistan's handling of the coronavirus pandemic, particularly Prime Minister Imran Khan's smart lockdown policy.
Dahroug stated that Egypt is also making efforts to combat COVID-19 and is following health guidelines and SOPs.
Dahroug emphasized the need to further expand bilateral relations between Egypt and Pakistan in various sectors, including culture, trade, tourism, and housing.
The Egyptian ambassador was briefed on the contributions of the Pakistan Observer and its founder, late editor-in-chief Zahid Malik, who advocated for strong relations between Pakistan and Arab countries.
4927cfd1c80288f68117a20f28680c9b:
Egyptian Prime Minister Mostafa Madbouly will visit Sudan on Saturday for one day.
Madbouly will be accompanied by ministers of irrigation, electricity, heath, and industry and trade, as well as high-profile officials from the transport and education ministries.
The visit will focus on cooperation in electric power interconnection, roads, railway connectivity, higher education, trade and industry.
Egypt and Sudan signed an electric power interconnection deal in April, aiming to provide Sudan with capacity of up to 70 megawatts per hour.
Madbouly's visit is the first since the formation of the transitional government in Sudan.
Egypt and Sudan have been engaged in negotiations with Ethiopia over the long-standing dispute over the hydroelectric dam Addis Ababa is building on the Blue Nile since 2011.
3287008b05f4b7154104bf14becbe7c7:
Egypt's Prime Minister Mostafa Madbouly arrived in Sudan for talks with his Sudanese counterpart Abdalla Hamdok and several ministers.
Extensive talks between the two countries’ delegations will be held on Saturday.
Madbouly’s visit comes few days ahead of an anticipated meeting between Egypt, Sudan and Ethiopia on Monday over the disputed Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam (GERD).
Sudan threatened to withdraw from the talks, sponsored by the African Union, if Ethiopia insisted on linking an agreement on the dam’s filling to negotiating a deal on sharing the waters of the Blue Nile.
Negotiations to reach a deal over the filling and operation of the nearly $5 billion GERD resumed one week after Cairo's call for a suspension of meetings after Addis Ababa put forward a new draft proposal that Cairo complained is lacking operating guidelines and any legally binding obligations.
Addis Ababa announced last month it had achieved its first-year target for the filling of the dam’s reservoir due to the rainfall season.
ae5e752aafa013e95360195b41c1a729:
Egypt's Prime Minister Mostafa Madbouly visited Khartoum, Sudan, and met with Sudanese Prime Minister Abdalla Hamdok to discuss mutual interests.
Egypt and Sudan agreed to increase the capacity of their electrical connectivity project from 70 megawatts to 300 megawatts.
Egypt sent two shipments of aid to Sudan, including baby formula, essential children's medicines, and medical equipment to combat hepatitis C.
Egypt and Sudan agreed to develop an action plan to overcome obstacles hindering commercial traffic and strengthen trade exchange.
The two countries discussed restructuring the Nile Valley Authority for River Navigation and linking railways to enhance economic and commercial cooperation.
Egypt and Sudan emphasized the importance of negotiations to reach a binding agreement on filling and operating the Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam (GERD).
Egypt reiterated its support for Sudan's transitional period and the aspirations of the Sudanese people.
69ee84f200e4a0d4f7ab2eb21b563ca5:
Egypt and Sudan are coordinating efforts to promote their development after 30 years of fraught relations.
Egypt and Sudan agreed to boost trade, cooperate over investment, and facilitate opportunities for Egyptian companies to invest in Sudan.
Egypt and Sudan agreed to restructure and develop the Nile Valley Authority for River Navigation.
Egypt and Sudan agreed to intensify cooperation in healthcare, education, and to further consolidate links between their power grids.
Egypt and Sudan reiterated their rejection of unilateral actions on the Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam (GERD) and stressed that current African Union-brokered talks should conclude in a legally binding agreement.
Egypt and Sudan have vast reserves of natural and human resources, share a common history, extensive cultural ties and a distinctive geographic location.
Egypt and Sudan have signed many protocols and agreements in the last 50 years, but they have almost always been consigned to the drawer.
The development needs of both Egypt and Sudan will best be served by removing impediments in the way of the free movement of people, capital and investments.
The Khartoum meeting sent a message to regional and international parties concerned with the GERD file that Egypt and Sudan have common interests and positions, their demands are fair, and that the ongoing dispute will only be resolved by a balanced and fair agreement.
29366910787e4425c0b1aeea3be667d1:
The Vatican presented Egypt’s Ambassador to the Holy See Mahmoud Sami with the Order of Knighthood.
The Vatican recognised Sami for his services in boosting relations between the Vatican and Egypt and supporting interfaith dialogue.
The accolade is an expression of appreciation from the Vatican for the friendly and stable relations with Egypt and the exchange of visits between high officials from both states.
3606ae6a5c375c84d02836173e0047f5:
Egyptian President Abdel-Fattah El-Sisi ratified a decree allowing Egypt to join the African Union (AU) Convention on Combating and Preventing Corruption.
The convention was signed in 2003 between AU member states in Mozambique and approved by the Egyptian parliament in 2017.
The AU Convention aims to promote, facilitate and regulate cooperation among AU countries to prevent, detect, punish and eradicate corruption and related offences.
48085564e9a271abd1fefbc3d55f1fbf:
Lebanese-Egyptian Business Council and Beirut Arab University signed a memorandum of understanding (MoU) to provide free Egyptian internships for Lebanese university students.
The MoU provides training for students in mechanical engineering, telecommunications engineering, petroleum engineering and pharmacy.
Students who complete the internship program will be given priority for employment at Egyptian companies.
The 45-day program includes a graduation project on an industrial idea involving Egypt and Lebanon.
The initiative will initially include 40 students in engineering and pharmacy and will later expand to include students in medical and nursing fields.
The Lebanese-Egyptian Business Council will cover all expenses for travel, accommodation and training for participants in the program.
The MoU is seen as a "glimmer of hope" for Lebanese students and youth amid difficult economic circumstances.
The initiative reflects 60 years of Egyptian-Lebanese cooperation and aims to help Lebanon "restore the pioneering role that it deserves."
5756b5f8decabb5dc428cbdffb5e95fd:
The World Tourism Organisation (UNWTO) is willing to cooperate with Egypt to ensure the optimal benefit from Egypt’s tourist destinations.
Egypt has resumed international flights on 1 July after three months of suspension due to the coronavirus pandemic.
Egypt has taken structural measures to rejuvenate tourism, such as merging the ministries of tourism and antiquities during the latest cabinet reshuffle in late 2019.
Egypt has implemented a number of projects in the tourism sector, such as Galala city in the northeastern governorate of Suez, New Alamein city in the northwestern governorate of Matrouh, and the Arts and Culture City in the New Administrative Capital, east Cairo.
Egypt has also implemented projects such as Giza’s Grand Egyptian Museum (GEM), the National Museum of Egyptian Civilisation in Old Cairo’s Fustat, and a “religious” project, named “The Greater Disclosure over the Land of Peace” in the Sinai Peninsula.
UNWTO chief Zurab Pololikashvili said he saw some of the mega projects that have been implemented in line with the highest international standards in tourism.
e14e70b94b422640a69973ad9ff5d601:
US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo visited Khartoum, the first high ranking US official to do so in three decades.
Pompeo met with Sudanese Prime Minister Abdalla Hamdok and the Chair of the Sudan Transitional Council Abdel-Fattah Al-Burhan.
The US is pressing Khartoum to move towards normalising relations with Israel as part of a package that would see it taken off the terrorism list.
Hamdok told Pompeo that such a decision could not be taken by a transitional government.
Khartoum is aware that Trump wants to score as many political victories for Israel as possible to secure maximum support from the Jewish lobby in the US ahead of the presidential elections in November.
Khartoum has agreed in principle to attend a meeting US and Bahrain are working on holding next month, possibly in Manama, so Israeli and Arab officials can explore different avenues towards normalisation.
Egypt is "all for" encouraging Sudan to move towards normalising ties with Israel.
Cairo has worked hard to secure closer coordination with Sudan on managing negotiations with Ethiopia over the filling and operation of the Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam (GERD).
Egypt is exploring the possibility of establishing a strategic partnership with Juba as well as Khartoum.
10c7d5325d9b07a2a93131e34f3ae1a3:
Egyptian Minister of State for Military Production Mohamed Ahmed Morsi met with Iraqi Ambassador to Egypt Ahmed Nayef al-Dleimy in Cairo.
Egypt and Iraq expressed willingness to enhance cooperation in civilian and military production.
Egypt's military production companies and their Iraqi counterparts explored the possibility of exchanging expertise and manufacturing technology.
Egypt's Minister of State for Military Production Mohamed Ahmed Morsi expressed willingness to deploy the ministry's technological means and human resources for the reconstruction of Iraq.
Iraqi Ambassador Ahmed Nayef al-Dleimy praised Egypt's Ministry of Military Production for its role in advancing both military and civilian industries.
Iraq's keenness to cooperate with Egypt's Ministry of Military Production comes as part of the technological, manufacturing, technical, research, and infrastructure capabilities of the latter's subsidiary companies.
The meeting comes amid a summit held by President Abdel Fatah al-Sisi, Jordanian King Abdallah al-Thani, and Iraqi Prime Minister Mustafa Kadhimi in Amman.
43fe296d0f748695b07542a385f75cd3:
The Egyptian Association of Graduates of Russian and Soviet Universities congratulated Russia’s ambassador to Egypt, Georgy Borisenko, on the 77th anniversary of the establishment of diplomatic relations between the two countries on 26 August, 1943.
The association president Sherif Gad said that in cooperation with the Soviet Union, about 100 projects were built, which are the most important infrastructure for the Egyptian economy, above all the Aswan High Dam.
The depth of bilateral relations is evident in the complete understanding between the two country’s leaderships and the great congruence in international positions shared by the two countries.
Joint cooperation continues in the construction of major projects such as the El Dabaa nuclear power plant and the Russian industrial zone in the Suez Canal region.
The Egyptian people regard Russia as the country’s main partner in development and that they are looking forward to more achievements through the agenda of the new ambassador.
The Egypt-Russia Cultural Year 2020 was transferred to 2021 so that “we can take advantage of this historic and unprecedented event in the history of bilateral relations between the two countries,” said Toughan.
c6bf5e3049b6032aaf3582b7d162c896:
Egypt and Pakistan will forge government-to-government (G2G) relations in the energy sector to strengthen economic ties between the two countries.
A delegation of Egyptian energy company Taqa accompanied the Ambassador of Egypt to Pakistan Tarek Dahrough in a meeting with Special Assistant to Prime Minister on Petroleum Nadeem Babar.
Pakistan’s energy mix would be diversified by injecting more hydel and renewable energy into the national grid.
The share of renewable energy in Pakistan is expected to increase to 20% by 2025 and 30% by 2030.
Representatives of the Egyptian energy company expressed interest in investing in the energy sector including power generation, transmission and distribution, projects related to renewable energy as well as in areas of liquefied natural gas (LNG), compressed natural gas (CNG) and gas distribution in Pakistan.
874eac3fa0361d426412ea9362ef9424:
New Ethiopian ambassador to Egypt Markos Tekle submitted a copy of his credentials to Assistant Foreign Minister for African Affairs Ambassador Abu Bakr Hefny to officially start his term.
Ethiopian ambassador Markos Tekle will seek to boost strong relations between Ethiopia and Egypt at the different social, political and economic levels.
Ethiopian ambassador Markos Tekle affirmed that the current talks among Ethiopia, Egypt and Sudan on the Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam (GERD) are going well.
Ethiopian ambassador Markos Tekle previously served as Ethiopia's ambassador to Japan and assumed the post of the director general of the diplomatic academy at the Ethiopian Ministry of Foreign Affairs, as well as an assistant professor at the School of Diplomacy and International Relations at the Ethiopian Civil Service University.
5a5401f3424d951eda4c5999b4542fe2:
Egypt’s President Abdel-Fattah El-Sisi praised Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe as a “patriotic statesman who gave much to his country.”
Abe announced his resignation on Friday over a resurgence of his ulcerative colitis.
Abe, 65, became Japan’s longest serving prime minister last year, ruling since 2012.
Abe met with El-Sisi in August last year on the sidelines of the Seventh Tokyo International Conference on African Development (TICAD).
The two sides discussed enhancing cooperation in the fields of basic education, higher education, culture, technology, energy and transport.
f3621eec274cf101ea2247972bdf77f7:
Egypt's pharaonic treasures are displayed for the first time at an exhibition in Prague, Czech Republic, to celebrate the 60th anniversary of the Czech archaeological mission in Egypt.
The exhibition, titled "Sun Kings," features 90 artifacts unearthed by the Czech mission in the archaeological area of Abu Sir, including the head of a statue of King "Ra-Nefer-F" and statues from the Old Kingdom.
The exhibition is the first to display Egyptian antiquities in Prague and the largest ever on Ancient Egypt.
The exhibition sheds light on the fifth dynasty (2435-2306 BC) and its kings known as "Sun Kings," who built their pyramids and temples in Abu Sir.
The artifacts displayed at the exhibition never left Egypt before and are set to be featured in the Grand Egyptian Museum after they return from Prague.
The Prague exhibition is expected to host up to 300,000 visitors.
812ec0ac2a9a23d536312c6be3b846a5:
High Representative of the EU for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy for the EU Josep Borrell visited Cairo on Thursday to discuss the latest events in neighboring Libya.
Egypt supports the Libyan National Army (LNA), the rival of the Turkish-backed Government of National Accord (GNA).
Egypt has warned that it will not allow Turkey or the GNA to seize control of the strategic city of Sirte.
642abc1ee37b55115a36d9e9a32ba9df:
Egyptian Deputy Foreign Minister for European Affairs Badr Abdel Aati met with Polish officials in Warsaw to discuss potential investment opportunities in Egypt for Poland.
Egypt is keen to enhance cooperation with Poland in several fields, including modern technology, information technology, and artificial intelligence.
Egypt and Poland aim to establish a Polish industrial zone in Egypt's Suez Canal Economic Zone (SCZone).
The Polish zone will provide ways to create investment opportunities for Polish companies in the Egyptian market.
Abdel Aati urged the establishment of an industrial zone for the Visegrad Group of countries, which includes Poland, Slovakia, Hungary and the Czech Republic, in the SCZone.
The meeting also covered the latest developments concerning the long-running dispute over the Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam (GERD), as well as updates on the situations in Libya and Syria, and on the Palestinian cause.
1d0a521cd1333ee3034a823e8b705f15:
Egyptian Foreign Minister Sameh Shoukry discussed the latest developments in the Eastern Mediterranean with his Emirati counterpart Abdullah bin Zayed.
Greece denied holding talks with Turkey, mediated by NATO, to ease tensions over maritime borders and gas exploration in the Eastern Mediterranean.
Turkey is provoking Greece by exploring gas in the Eastern Mediterranean on its own, a move that was met with great international condemnation.
Egypt and Greece signed an agreement to demarcate the maritime borders between them, which Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan described as worthless.
US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo called on Athens and Ankara to de-escalate tension in the Eastern Mediterranean around the maritime borders and energy reserves in the region.
06ef12b2d51fb14e6e86c60e1fb2c0f8:
Japan will support Egypt in its green energy agenda and digital transition to combat the impacts of coronavirus.
Japan and Egypt will implement development projects in health, agriculture, aviation, electricity, transportation, and the environment, and promote knowledge exchange in science and technology.
Japan has invested in 12 projects in Egypt worth $2 billion, including the Egyptian Japanese University of Science, the Abu Rish University Hospital project, the Japanese schools project, and the renewable energy project.
Japan's International Cooperation Agency aims to focus on expanding renewable energy, digital transition, and improving health facilities in Egypt to support a post-Covid-19 recovery.
Japan has been supporting Egypt's development in various sectors since 1954, with $1.3 billion of aid overall, and $6.8 billion in loans for the energy, health, transport, tourism and education sectors.
fc388f91282a935139140acfdd878f80:
Egyptian and Maltese foreign ministers met in Cairo to discuss cooperation in combating illegal immigration and regional issues.
Egypt and Malta emphasized the need to address the root causes of illegal immigration and share responsibility among Mediterranean countries and EU member states.
Egypt and Malta exchanged views on the Libyan crisis, with Egypt reiterating the need for a ceasefire and a halt to the flow of weapons and foreign fighters into Libya.
Egypt reaffirmed its support for the two-state solution to the Palestinian-Israeli conflict and efforts to bring peace and preserve Palestinian rights.
Egypt and Malta agreed to expand cooperation in trade and investment.
The Maltese foreign minister also met with the Arab League Secretary-General to discuss the Libyan conflict, the Palestinian cause, and other issues.
da9c8bffeb251f1aa865094d23cd55c4:
Egypt's Irrigation and Water Resources Minister Mohamed Abdel Aty visited South Sudan to discuss cooperation in irrigation and water resources with his South Sudanese counterpart Manawa Peter Gatkuoth.
This is the first meeting between the two ministers since Gatkuoth assumed his post.
The two countries signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) in August 2006, a technical cooperation protocol in March 2011, and a development and technical cooperation agreement in November 2014.
As per the 2014 agreement, the Egyptian irrigation ministry has been implementing several development projects in South Sudan, including providing clean drinking water and establishing marinas.
Abdel-Aty is set to inspect work at underground reservoirs in South Sudan's Juba.
The visit is the latest in a series of visits by officials from Egypt in the past few months to provide support to South Sudan and discuss cooperation.
75677b1fd99ab8160aab46b3e5a8f066:
Egypt’s Social Solidarity Minister Nevin El-Qabbaj and USAID’s new Egypt director Leslie Reed met virtually to discuss cooperation in various fields.
The pair discussed cooperation in response to the implications of the coronavirus pandemic, social protection, economic empowerment, crises and relief, efforts to combat all forms of violence against women, and support centres that host abused women.
Egypt’s Social Solidarity Minister Nevin El-Qabbaj added that the ministry is close to issuing the executive regulations on the new NGO law.
USAID’s new Egypt director Leslie Reed hailed Egypt’s efforts in the field of social protection and the amended NGO law.
The House of Representatives passed an amended NGO law in July 2019.
f33e966dda710fadfca6ad88f313916e:
Egyptian President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi and French President Emmanuel Macron discussed regional issues, including the situation in Libya.
Sisi and Macron rejected escalation in eastern Mediterranean and stressed the priority of achieving security and stability in the region.
Sisi and Macron supported a political solution to the crisis in Libya away from foreign interference and armed militias.
Sisi and Macron welcomed positive steps to reach a peaceful settlement in Libya.
Sisi and Macron stressed the importance of intensifying bilateral coordination to support Lebanon.
Sisi and Macron highlighted the need to back Lebanon to face economic and political challenges.
Sisi and Macron agreed to push international action towards the resumption of Palestinian-Israeli negotiations.
f71b02372dbe677cfba4f3113d974c3e:
Azerbaijani Foreign Minister Jeyhun Bayramov received Egyptian Ambassador Adel Ibrahim on September 11.
Bayramov emphasized the importance of Azerbaijan-Egypt relations in various areas, including politics, economics, and culture.
Ambassador Ibrahim conveyed congratulations from Egyptian Foreign Minister Sameh Shoukry and invited Bayramov for an official visit to Egypt.
Both sides discussed potential for enhancing economic, trade, and tourism ties.
Bayramov briefed Ibrahim on the Nagorno-Karabakh conflict, Armenia's aggression, and the need for Armenia to withdraw from occupied territories.
Ambassador Ibrahim expressed Egypt's support for Azerbaijan's territorial integrity and advocated for a peaceful settlement of the conflict.
1098f8e626ab87579a3ac4ccdc6938c8:
Egyptian President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi and French President Emmanuel Macron discussed regional issues, including Libya, on Friday.
Sisi and Macron rejected escalation in eastern Mediterranean which affects the interests of the countries of the region, stressing that achieving security and stability in the region is a priority that requires coordination between Egypt and France.
Sisi and Macron stressed their support for a political solution to the crisis in Libya away from foreign interference and armed militias.
Sisi and Macron welcomed positive steps to reach a peaceful settlement in Libya, within the framework of constructive international efforts.
Sisi and Macron stressed the importance of intensifying bilateral coordination to support the government and people of Lebanon by all possible means to overcome the repercussions of the Beirut's port explosion disaster.
Sisi and Macron highlighted the need to back Lebanon to face the current economic and political challenges the country is going through in order to preserve its stability, sovereignty and unity.
Sisi and Macron agreed that international action should be pushed towards the resumption of Palestinian-Israeli negotiations with the aim of reaching a just and comprehensive settlement in a manner that opens prospects for stability and prosperity for all peoples of the region.
c9e5d29df320bc1d9a468b71eb882835:
Egypt and Armenia held talks to bolster bilateral relations and discuss regional and international developments.
Egypt and Armenia have a strong political will to boost cooperation in various economic and political fields.
Armenia's foreign minister stressed the importance of respecting state sovereignty and working towards peace and stability in the East Mediterranean and North Africa.
Armenia supports Cyprus and Greece for investments in economic zones amid an ongoing rift with Turkey.
Tensions in the region have escalated in the past months over Turkey's military intervention in Libya, its violation of Iraq's sovereignty, and its hunt for gas in the eastern Mediterranean in violation of the territorial waters of Greece and Cyprus.
89d97f727c5c2bec25cd21a6f06448ba:
Egyptian Foreign Minister Sameh Shoukry and Russian counterpart Sergei Lavrov discussed regional issues, including the situation in Libya.
Shoukry highlighted the importance of reaching a comprehensive cease-fire agreement in Libya, as well as the need to bust all armed militias.
Shoukry underlined the the pullout of all foreign forces from Libya, and active negotiations to reach a political solution.
Shoukry and Lavrov also discussed developments in Syria, noting the need to reach a comprehensive settlement of the crisis on the basis of UN references.
Shoukry emphasized the need to preserve the legitimate Palestinian rights and the principle of the two-state solution within the framework of international legitimacy resolutions.
d0fbb7394b20970e674a5b23bd1d9316:
Egypt's President Abdel Fattah Al-Sisi and the Minister of Foreign Affairs of Armenia Zohrab Mnatsakanyan have agreed on the importance of undermining foreign interference in the region.
Al-Sisi and Mnatsakanyan discussed bilateral relations as well as regional developments, mainly in Libya, Syria, Lebanon and the Palestinian issue.
Al-Sisi and Mnatsakanyan agreed on the importance of undermining foreign interference in the region which seeks "to achieve direct gains in favour of its own ambitions and self-benefit at the expense of security, stability and the people's capabilities".
Al-Sisi and Mnatsakanyan discussed bilateral cooperation including increasing mutual investment opportunities and maximizing the volume of trade exchange, especially in the fields of pharmaceutical industries, technical education and tourism.
Al-Sisi and Mnatsakanyan discussed coordination and information exchange between the two countries.
679610d95b737a8fdd72c6d13958545a:
Sheikh Mohamed bin Zayed, Crown Prince of Abu Dhabi and Deputy Supreme Commander of the UAE Armed Forces, received a phone call from French President Emmanuel Macron on Saturday.
Sheikh Mohamed and President Macron discussed ways to enhance bilateral relations and cooperation between the two countries.
Sheikh Mohamed and President Macron tackled the latest Middle East developments, issues of mutual interest and the two countries' effort to support regional peace and stability.
Sheikh Mohamed and President Macron emphasized the importance of the historic peace accord between the UAE and Israel in strengthening stability, security and peace and in bringing about development and achieving a prosperous future for the people of the region.
e43975df354b07919e6d32f64ad26a1a:
Egyptian Minister of Culture Ines Abdel-Dayem has inaugurated a series of seminars dubbed 'Cultural Relations' to strengthen creative cooperation between Egypt and countries around the world.
The first seminar celebrated Mexico's National Day.
The 'Cultural Relations' seminars aim to consolidate the bonds of friendship between Egypt and the various countries of the world.
Egyptian Minister of Culture Ines Abdel-Dayem congratulated Ambassador Tripp on the occasion of his country’s national day and handed him a selection of the Ministry of Culture publications translated to English and Spanish.
Ambassador Tripp said that Egypt and Mexico are world powers in cultural terms due to their millennial and prestigious backgrounds.
Ambassador Tripp said that Mexico and Egypt have a dynamic interaction in several and diverse areas of the cultural spectrum.
Ambassador Tripp said that Egypt and Mexico must be more ambitious in order to make possible a formal and systematic interaction between the cultural communities of both countries offering economic opportunities for artists and creators from Mexico and Egypt.
267bb3541ea67079dbdc53ddd5c4ccfe:
Egypt’s foreign minister Sameh Shoukry and EU Neighbourhood and Enlargement Commissioner Olivér Várhelyi discussed boosting cooperation between Egypt and the European Union (EU).
Shoukry and Várhelyi agreed to enhance development and economic benefits from the EU-Egypt Association Agreement.
Egypt seeks to attract more European investments and facilitate exports to EU markets.
Egypt is open to tripartite cooperation with the EU in African countries to support development efforts.
Várhelyi acknowledged Egypt's role in regional stability and security.
Shoukry and Várhelyi addressed regional developments and challenges facing Egypt and the EU.
affbd58cb96ef4c1b809934b62e7a74c:
Egypt supports efforts to boost South-South cooperation.
Egypt is committed to establishing a new partnership to foster South-South cooperation to implement the UN 2030 and AU 2063 agendas.
The Egyptian Agency of Partnership for Development (EAPD) plays a role in boosting South-South cooperation.
Egypt supports all national, regional and international efforts to eradicate poverty.
73d16299288c91e6a6df92d0ba630ede:
Eleven people died from COVID-19 and 1,229 tested positive for the coronavirus in Israel between midnight and 7pm Tuesday.
The death toll from the virus in Israel now stands at 956.
17,527 tests were conducted throughout the country in that period, yielding a positive infection rate of 7.3 percent.
There are currently 20,960 people actively suffering from COVID-19 in the country, with 415 people in serious condition and 117 on ventilators.
Schools in Israel opened their doors to students with the exception of education facilities in communities with a high infection rate, which Health Ministry ordered to remain closed.
Israel's 2,400,000 schoolchildren began the academic year in kindergartens, schools and via remote learning, including 169,000 children who took their first steps into grade 1 classes.
Coronavirus cabinet voted late on Monday that schools in 23 "red" cities and communities, where the COVID-19 infection rate is exceptionally high, were to remain closed.
The decision left more than 140,000 children of all ages at home.
The Haredi West Bank settlement of Beitar Illit, however, opened its schools on the first day of the academic year despite the ministry order, claiming that the directive discriminates against ultra-Orthodox public.
2d725c52664a19523d5233e262df7dab:
Israel is the world's leading country with regards to the spread of the coronavirus.
The new infection rate in Israel reached 199.3 per million citizens every day last week.
3,074 cases were detected in one day, including 700 among Palestinian Arab citizens alone.
The infection rate among those who underwent a test is 9.4 per cent.
The Israeli Ministerial Committee in charge of coronavirus affairs decided to impose a complete closure on around thirty towns classified as "red" due to the high number of cases.
The restrictions imposed on cities classified as "red" include closing the educational institutions, closing the commercial enterprises apart from essential places, restrictions on the movement of citizens, and restriction of movement at a distance of 500 metres from the place of residence in areas that are largely affected by the pandemic.
The ongoing debate within the Ministerial Committee for Coronavirus Affairs is heading towards imposing partial closures and restrictions on the 34 red towns, in addition to imposing a complete closure on four of these towns.
These restrictions and night closures are the result of serious recklessness and failure to adhere to the Ministry of Health's instructions, and therefore they aim to limit the organisation of wedding parties, which are the first source of infection in the red-listed towns.
There is currently a state of chaos and turmoil in Israel due to the widespread infection during the second wave of the virus.
Ministers of the ultra-Orthodox Jews threaten to withdraw from the government if restrictions are imposed on their people during the Jewish holidays in the middle of this month.
Controversy is growing in Israel over who bears responsibility for the failure and how to deal with coronavirus through complete closure or selective localisation.
The organisation of weddings and large meetings is considered to be one of the causes of the outbreak of the pandemic.
This instability runs concurrently in the midst of a stifling economic crisis, manifested by a million unemployed persons in Israel.
fb25dc25422acbc4f8ef8be901a4e6d0:
Israel's death toll from coronavirus has surpassed 1,000, with 12 additional fatalities reported.
2,617 new coronavirus cases were confirmed in Israel, with a positivity rate of 8.2%.
439 coronavirus patients are in serious condition, including 128 on ventilators.

The British medical journal Lancet put the figure as low as five in its latest report.
The Lancet article, published Monday, put the issue of reinfection on the global health agenda, as it documented America’s first confirmed case of SARS-CoV-2 reinfection.
Dutch authorities reported what is believed to be the first death as a result of reinfection.
The deceased is an 89-year-old immunocompromised woman, who tested positive, recovered, and 59 days later fell ill and once again tested positive.
In the American case outlined in the Lancet, the patient was a 25-year-old man from Nevada, who had no known immune disorders.
The documented Israeli patient had mild symptoms the first time around and, upon second infection, was asymptomatic with the exception of an elevated heart rate.
The Lancet reported that with the American patient, “what is worrisome is that SARS-CoV-2 reinfection resulted in worse disease than did the first infection, requiring oxygen support and hospitalization.”
The confirmed Israeli case was documented, peer-reviewed and published by Nachmias and colleagues from the Leumit health organization in the journal IDCases.
The patient was a 20-year-old woman from Bnei Brak, healthy until she caught the coronavirus.
She was diagnosed on April 17, and tested negative on May 1 and May 10.
The patient then went for screening on August 6 and on August 11, and tested positive both times.
Nachmias said that upon the second infection, she had a blood sample drawn for analysis and found that antibodies were present.
Nachmias said that she doesn’t have an explanation for what went wrong to result in the reinfection, but she raised the fear of a changing virus that would undermine immunity.
Bar Ilan University immunologist Cyrille Cohen thinks the mutation theory is unlikely.
Cohen said that SARS-CoV-2 appears to result in immunity, with some rare exceptions, which isn’t unusual as infections from the coronavirus family go.
Nachmias suspects reinfection is being underdiagnosed by doctors who simply don’t test recovered patients because they assume immunity.
Tel Aviv University professor Mordechai Gerlic told The Times of Israel he suspects that mistakes account for some reports of reinfection, saying they diagnoses may well reflect testing errors, or patients who never fully recovered from their first infection.
503b296f2177474294ab5b8ee02e598d:
Thousands of Israelis gathered outside Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's official residence in Jerusalem and at other locations around the country for the 11th consecutive week, calling on the prime minister to resign in light of his ongoing corruption trial.
Police forces tried to stop the group from marching through Jaffa Street towards Netanyahu's residence, but protesters removed police barriers and brief clashes ensued.
At least 12 arrests were made, and on Sunday a district court extended the detention of five protesters who tried to remove the barriers until Monday afternoon.
Prominent artist and activist Zeev Engelmayer, who regularly participates in the weekly demonstrations in the costume of his female character Shoshke, was stopped at the entrance to the demonstration and prevented from entering it.
Additional demonstrations were held at intersections and on bridges across the country, as well as near Netanyahu's private residence in Caesarea, where hundreds gathered.
About 40 supporters of the prime minister showed up for a counter-demonstration.
Several dozen people also protested against Netanyahu's government on bridges in the Arab cities of Taibeh and Nazareth.
On Friday night, thirteen anti-government activists were arrested for attempting to load several police crowd control barriers onto a truck, ahead of Saturday's demonstration outside the prime minister's official residence in Jerusalem.
03cd140f4170b7824b40c6ceec565b5d:
Thousands of Israelis protested against Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu for the 12th straight week on Saturday.
Anti-corruption demonstrators were joined by business owners protesting the potential damage of a looming country-wide lockdown.
The protest ended after midnight as police forcibly cleared out the remaining protesters who refused to leave.
Nine people were arrested for disturbing public order or attacking officers.
The protest began with a march to the prime minister’s official residence in the capital’s Balfour Street from the Chords Bridge at the entrance to the city.
Protesters chanted “You take from the poor and give to the rich, what a corrupt government!”
Lawyer Wajdi Haj Yehia said they had shown up every week to demonstrate “against corruption, against racism and against the policy of this government at whose head stands Benjamin Netanyahu.”
Saturday’s protest was expected to be the last before new national lockdown measures are enacted next week.
Many of the protesters chanted against the planned lockdown.
Others protested what they said was the detachment from the public’s travails shown by the prime minister, who was set to leave for Washington Sunday to celebrate normalization agreements with the UAE and Bahrain.
Protest organizers at Balfour called for demonstrations at the airport to “detain” Netanyahu’s flight Sunday.
Police said Engelmayer’s suit, a fixture at protests in past weeks, could be a form of “sexual harassment against the public,” a charge that does not appear to exist in Israeli law books.
Jerusalem Police Operations Commander Alon Khalfon said the protests were largely peaceful, but some demonstrators “clashed with police” and attacked them.
Demonstrators have held regular protests this summer against Netanyahu in Jerusalem, Tel Aviv and other locations across the country.
On Friday, thousands of Israelis marched in central Jerusalem and then rallied outside Netanyahu’s residence to protest against the premier over his indictment on corruption charges and handling of the coronavirus pandemic.
Over 6,000 people attended Friday’s protest.
c96d5baa57ea40e3e0e60254bb655d37:
Protesters gathered outside Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s official residence in Jerusalem to protest a nearing nationwide lockdown.
Israel plans to impose a new lockdown, which will go into effect sometime before Rosh Hashanah next week and is expected to last several weeks.
Israel is among the only industrialized countries to require a second shutdown, after fully reopening the economy and allowing morbidity rates to skyrocket over the summer.
Some business owners have protested and some threatened to disobey guidelines and open anyway, citing the high financial toll of the measure.
Performance artist Ariel Barnoz chained himself to a traffic pole — while only wearing underwear — in a statement against the planned measures.
Protesters were also incensed by the fact that Netanyahu would be jetting off to Washington for a signing ceremony with the United Arab Emirates as the rest of the country was preparing to be locked down.
Protesters said Saturday that they were planning to converge on Ben-Gurion airport on Sunday to stop Netanyahu’s plane.
Protesters insisted they would be back after the Jewish holiday of Rosh Hashanah.
9394f2dfacafd1cbd501f6a59a37fa53:
Several thousand protesters demonstrated against Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu near his official residence in Jerusalem, despite a nationwide coronavirus lockdown.
Police arrested 11 protesters for disturbance of the peace and assaulting a police officer.
Police arrested a driver who was speeding near the protest site, putting protesters and police officers in danger.
Protesters called on Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to resign, citing his trial in three corruption cases, the government's response to the coronavirus outbreak, and an ongoing economic crisis.
Police set up barriers at the main protest site in Jerusalem, but most protesters ignored them.
Police officials said they wouldn't enforce new directives that require demonstrators to stay within separated groups of up to 20 people.
Ultra-Orthodox protesters demonstrated in five cities over the lockdown's impact on religious life and citizens' welfare.
Several demonstrators in Bnei Brak torched garbage bins and hurled stones at police officers, resulting in one arrest and damage to a patrol vehicle.
Protests are allowed during the three-week lockdown, but demonstrators must stay within separated groups of up to 20 people and wear face masks at all times.
The space allocated for the protest against Netanyahu in Jerusalem will be expanded to allow protesters to maintain social distancing.

Police arrested a man on Sunday night who was speeding toward barricades set up around a protest in Jerusalem.
Police said they had “arrested a suspect who drove toward the police barricades and was a danger to protestors and police.”
Police did not immediately specify whether the incident was a near-accident or an intended attack.
Video posted to social media showed a white Mini Cooper car coming to a screeching halt as officers called on the driver to stop, some of them with their guns drawn.
Police then pulled the driver from the vehicle and wrestled him to the ground.
Toward the end of the video, one officer appears to punch the suspect in the groin area before grasping him by the neck.
Police said the man was taken for questioning, but provided no further details on his identity or possible motivation.
It was not immediately clear if the incident was an attempted attack or an accident.
Some 3,000 people gathered late Sunday for the weekly protest against Netanyahu outside his official residence in Jerusalem.
Netanyahu is charged with fraud, breach of trust and accepting bribes in three separate cases.
His criminal trial began in June, but he has refused to step down from office and denies any wrongdoing.
Many demonstrators also protested against his handling of the coronavirus crisis.
Police tried to divide demonstrators into “capsules” of 20 people, but did not physically enforce the efforts as the new guidelines are currently just a suggestion and have not yet been approved by the government.
The weekly protests in Jerusalem and elsewhere across Israel are usually held on Saturday evenings after Shabbat, but this week they were pushed off until Sunday night, when the Jewish New Year holiday ends.
Police said they had handed out 2,802 fines over the past day for various infractions of the lockdown rules and other coronavirus regulations.
Israel, which has one of the highest daily infection rates per capita in the world, became the first developed country to order a second lockdown to fight the pandemic.
Israel’s coronavirus czar warned Sunday that virus numbers were reaching “emergency,” levels that could see the country face 600 deaths a month and ordering hospitals to add new virus wards.
The Health Ministry on Sunday reported another 1,906 coronavirus cases since midnight Saturday, bringing the number of infections since the pandemic began to 187,396.
935fe6bb8c5c66f40a86cc857b7a7e73:
Hundreds of people took part in demonstrations calling for Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s resignation around the country Thursday.
The largest gathering took place near Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s official residence in Jerusalem.
Under restrictions set to go into effect at 2 p.m. on Friday, people will be prevented from venturing more than one kilometer from their home in order to protest and rallies will be limited to groups of 20.
Protests outside Netanyahu’s residence will be allowed to continue with up to 2,000 participants at a time, as long as they are divided into 20-person “capsules.”
Former Air Force brigadier general Amir Haskel said that the restrictions on demonstrations were about politics, not public health.

The Knesset’s Constitution Law and Justice Committee authorized the government’s emergency regulations to limit crowding, which went into effect at midnight Thursday and will remain in force at least until October 7.

Yamina MK Ayelet Shaked, Yisrael Beytenu MK Oded Forer, and others said they were shocked to learn that small businesses were also included among gatherings the emergency regulations aimed at limiting.

The Armenian military adviser to the Armenian prime minister, Vagharshak Harutyunyan, openly stated on Russian TV’s Vesti news program that the Armenian army is deliberately targeting the civilian population of Azerbaijan to create panic.
For 30 years, the two sides have not been able to settle the conflict.

Four United Nations resolutions and a UN General Assembly resolution have reaffirmed Azerbaijan’s territorial integrity calling on Armenia to withdraw its armed forces.
Armenia and Azerbaijan are among the most militarized states in the world, with both being primarily armed by Russia.
