Egypt's President Abdel-Fattah El-Sisi inaugurated the El-Fayrouz fish farming project in Port Said, which includes two fishing lakes, 5,908 tanks, and a fish processing factory.
The project aims to reduce fish imports, increase exports, and create 10,000 jobs.
El-Sisi also opened a fish farming project at Deeba Triangle in west Port Said.
Other projects inaugurated include dairy and livestock projects in Fayoum and Nubaria, and marble and granite projects in Ras Sedr and Ain Sokhna.
El-Sisi emphasized the challenge of overpopulation, which hinders development efforts.
Egypt is upgrading 10,000 kilometers of railway lines and plans to establish a new railway line between 6 October city and Aswan.
Prime Minister Mostafa Madbouly highlighted state projects under Egypt's 2030 strategy, including 31,000 projects to improve people's lives, 30 new cities, and investments in dry ports, electricity, and universities.
d2cff83c66b8cac618907434df45e333:
Uber Ignite series is a new series of talks that brings together thought leaders, regulators, corporates, start-ups, and innovators to collectively address a number of urban challenges in the MENA region.
Egypt needs to extend more incentives to encourage individuals to convert their fuel-run vehicles to become eco-friendly.
10 percent of road accidents are caused by heavy-trucks, and 6 percent of these accidents lead to 10 percent of deaths.
90 percent of road accidents are a result of a human error.
95 percent of goods in Egypt are transported using heavy trucks.
There is great room for the private sector to play a role in transport safety through investing in transport safety technologies.
bdcf78b9e73b735cd78c2cba4d2f6d01:
Egypt's Foreign Minister Sameh Shoukry affirmed Egypt's commitment to support efforts to provide adequate and sustainable financing for the United Nations Peacebuilding Fund during Egypt's presidency of the Peacebuilding Commission this year.
Shoukry voiced out Egypt's support for the UN Secretary-General's strategy for the Peacebuilding Fund for the period 2020 - 2024, which includes a vision of how to employ the activities of the fund and its resources to address the political, economic and social repercussions resulting from the coronavirus pandemic.
Shoukry highlighted the "major" challenge the pandemic constitutes to international peace and security saying it has "a profound impact on exacerbating conflict-causing conditions and weakening state institutions."
The United Nations event was co-chaired by the UN Secretary-General, António Guterres, and others officials under the theme "A high-level Replenishment Conference for the Peacebuilding Fund to mobilize critical support for conflict prevention and peacebuilding against the Fund’s $1.5 billion requirements for the period 2020-24.”
The Egyptian foreign minister also asserted the need to rely on "innovative" financial sources to finance the fund in order to avoid relying on voluntary financial contributions.
The UN event aimed to counter the persistent underinvestment in peacebuilding and provide this timely, catalytic and risk-tolerant instrument with more adequate, predictable and sustained resources to support national peacebuilding efforts in more than 40 countries around the world.
b2527cd5e93029e6eef72ee1e135bcef: French shipping group CMA CGM has reached an agreement with Egypt to operate a future container terminal at the port of Alexandria.
Operations at the planned terminal are due to start in 2022.
a6c14bbbc0838ed9cefb008b678fd0e4:
Egypt and Sudan are making new efforts to boost economic and trade relations.
Egypt's Minister of Trade and Industry Nevine Gamea met with her Sudanese counterparts to discuss increasing bilateral trade cooperation.
Egypt was the guest of honour at the Khartoum International Fair from 21 to 28 January in the Sudanese capital.
The meetings focused on renewing the licence for the Egyptian Trade Centre in Sudan to make Egyptian goods available to Sudanese consumers at a lower cost and in a shorter time.
Trade between Egypt and Sudan last year reached $862 million, with $496 million of Egyptian exports to Sudan and $366 million of imports.
The most important items traded between the two countries are chemicals, manufactured products, machinery and equipment, food products, textiles, transportation materials, livestock, and agricultural products.
Egypt and Sudan have discussed a project to link the railways of the two countries to increase economic and trade cooperation.
Egypt and Sudan have also discussed an agreement on credit arrangements to increase Egyptian exports to Sudan.
Egypt has established 229 projects in Sudan between 2000 and 2013, representing a total investment of $10.8 billion.
ba9725ce1d8e2e0fc496c0e9e55b4a02:
Egypt and the UAE have signed an agreement to cooperate in the field of digital transformation.
Egypt aims to provide customized training programs for freelance professionals across the country.
Egypt is establishing the Misr Informatics University and the Egypt Digital Builders initiative to develop digital cadres.
Egypt has adopted policies to facilitate the establishment of small and medium-sized companies.
Egypt is implementing an ambitious strategy to achieve digital financial inclusion.
Egypt has ratified the African Continental Free Trade Agreement and is ready to join efforts with African countries to link supply chains.
c9da9012bd4dc400d14d914aec54cd8b:
Egypt plans to increase its exports of construction materials to Iraq to $7 billion.
Egyptian companies are in charge of reconstruction in the Iraqi governorates of Nineveh, Saladin and Anbar, in addition to the district of Samara.
20 Egyptian companies will participate in building housing units in 15 Iraqi governorates.
Egyptian companies are expected to build restaurants, hotels, resorts, 35 hospitals in ten governorates and develop natural gas-fired power plants.
4ed25ea3194b06c86f490651ea5f133a:
President Abdel-Fattah El-Sisi inspected developmental road projects in Old Cairo and East Cairo.
A network of bridges has been constructed to link Old Cairo's Civilizations Axis area with the main roads of Cairo.
The historic Ain Al-Sira area and the vicinity of the National Museum of Egyptian Civilization in Old Cairo are being developed.
Slums in the vicinity of Old Cairo's Al-Sayeda Aisha district have been removed, and residents have been moved to new cities.
The state plans to restore Old Cairo's civilizational splendor and historic heritage, including the Fustat area, the Cairo Citadel Aqueduct, the Religions Complex, and historic mosques.
President Sisi inspected road projects in the districts of Nasr City, Heliopolis, and Autostrad in East Cairo.
President Sisi urged officials and supervisors to adhere to the timeframes set to implement these projects in accordance to the highest standards.
367840b79a3fa17ffd582ba6177b0905:
Two Czech social influencers visited Hurghada in a trip organized by the Egyptian Ministry of Tourism and Antiquities to promote tourism.
The Czech bloggers went diving in the Red Sea and visited the Hurghada Museum, where they praised the display of Tutankhamun's artefacts.
The Grand Egyptian Museum (GEM), which was listed as one of the top attractions to visit this year by CNN, is scheduled for inauguration this year.
The Czech bloggers also visited the Giza Pyramids, Saqqara Necropolis, the Step Pyramid of Djoser, and Khan Al-Khalili Bazaar in Cairo.
The Czech bloggers will next head to Luxor to tour its archaeological attractions.
Egypt has received 1.4 million tourists since reopening its seaside resorts to international flights in July.
cfa99e69e7c13d7026219331f2770c50:
Egypt and France will finalize details of bilateral projects under Egypt’s sustainable development 2030 agenda during the visit of French Minister of Finance in February.
Egypt and France have begun negotiating the allocation and execution of development financing projects via French companies.
The bilateral partnership between Egypt and France aims to achieve the UN’s sustainable development goals and support Egypt’s national agenda 2030.
In December, Egypt and France signed three financing agreements worth €715.6 million to support the health, transportation, education, and water sectors.
The history of cooperation between Egypt and France dates back to 1974, with an economic cooperation portfolio worth €7.5 billion.
The current cooperation portfolio between Egypt and France rounds up to €1 billion.
3fcefc1e1efb3f3237ad6ff444c36bf7:
Egypt's government has launched the second phase of initiative supporting export companies, with registration opening from 7 February to the end of the month.
The initiative aims to disburse the export companies' arrears from the Export Development Fund (EDF) before the end of the current FY2020/2021 (ending in June).
The second phase of the initiative will be executed with the same conditions of the first phase.
The initiative contributes in providing cash liquidity that enables export companies to meet their financial obligations, keep their labour force and boost the competitiveness of Egyptian products in international markets.
In September, Egypt’s government launched the first phase of the initiative that targeted instant and cash repayment of the entirety of export companies’ arrears from the EDF before the end of 2020 at a repay acceleration discount of 15 percent.
1069 export companies benefitted from the first phase, with total disbursements of EGP 13.5 billion.
The initiative is implemented in collaboration with the banking system, as the finance ministry deposits a guarantee at the Central Bank of Egypt (CBE) to allow for the payment of the arrears for the companies that are willing to pay their entire dues.
The finance ministry will repay these sums and their proceeds to the banks that contributed to the initiative over three years.
The government disbursed EGP 21 billion over a year in order to support the exports sector through six initiatives.
2500 export companies benefitted from the other five initiatives with a total of EGP 5.6 billion disbursed for the exports during FY2019/2020 as well as EGP 2.4 billion disbursed from July to November 2020.
The cabinet has approved five initiatives since October 2019 that aimed to settle the exporters’ arrears through June 2019.
7c85545e062b749d3bc3e1e77ed2a34e:
Egypt’s Minister of International Cooperation, Rania Al-Mashat, met with the Ambassador of Belgium, François Cornet D’Elzius, to discuss future plans of bilateral cooperation between the countries.
Egypt and Belgium have been working on various agreements with the European Union regarding projects listed for development financing for 2022.
Belgium is eager to further cooperate with Egypt on the development of micro, small, and medium-sized enterprises, and on the establishment of a strong public-private dialogue in the Egyptian business sphere.
Egypt and Belgium have cooperated on the restoration project of the Baron Palace, under the debt-swap programme between both countries, for an agreement worth €2.14 million (EGP 16 million).
The Ministry of International Cooperation secured development financing agreements worth $9.8 billion during 2020; $6.7 billion of which were for financing sovereign projects, and $3.1 billion for supporting the private sector.
ca3887364e47457dc56c3141f6bf3703:
Egypt’s President Abdel-Fattah El-Sisi stressed the importance of inter-Arab cooperation in the area of intelligence during the inauguration of the Arab Intelligence Forum 2021 in Cairo.
El-Sisi asserted the importance of empowering the forum as a strong and supportive mechanism for cooperation in intelligence between Arab countries.
The forum should work on a counterterrorism system that depends on exchanging expertise.
El-Sisi stressed the importance of Arab countries cooperating to restore stability in all the region’s countries, where terrorist organisations attempt to expand with the support of foreign forces that aim to create chaos to control the resources and capabilities of the Arab world.
The heads of intelligence agencies who participated in the forum stressed the importance of the platform in boosting cooperation to protect Arab national security by exchanging points of view on dealing with the rapid challenges facing the region, especially in counterterrorism, organised crime and radical thought.
6664e76a712654626c5418bd9736230c:
Egypt is adopting a vast infrastructure plan to link nine African countries, including Sudan, with the largest land road in Africa.
The project aims to create a route from Salloum to Benghazi, supporting Egyptian industry and labor and contributing to the transport of goods to Libya.
The development of the railway system comes in parallel with the establishment of the express electric train, aiming to achieve safety and avoid human errors.
The Egyptian state is making great efforts to develop land and dry ports, with a comprehensive plan to establish 13 ports and a logistical center.
The new Egyptian ports aim to facilitate internal and external trade movement, support the Egyptian economy, prevent the accumulation of goods and containers in sea ports and achieve integration between means of transportation.
A total of 35 projects were planned, with a total cost of 15 billion Egyptian pounds ($951,000).
Nine projects have already been completed at a total cost of 300 million pounds, including the construction of the Qustul land port, the Arqin land port, and development of the Taba land port.
5886eb4cfaded506886a820fcead22a2:
Egypt's Foreign Minister Sameh Shoukry and his Brazilian counterpart, Ernesto Araujo, discussed ways to encourage more cooperation between the private sectors in both countries.
Shoukry and Araujo urged cooperation between private sector companies in agriculture, medical and pharmaceutical research, as well as science and technology.
They also agreed on enhancing commercial relations and investments between Egypt and the Mercosur, the South American trade bloc.
The two ministers affirmed the need for cooperation between the two countries within the framework of the projects that Egypt is implementing in Africa.
They also discussed the latest in the dispute over the Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam.
Shoukry stressed to his Brazilian counterpart Egypt's insistence on the need to reach a legally binding agreement on the filling and operating of the Ethiopian dam through engaging in serious talks “without procrastination.”
In 2018, trade exchange between Egypt and Brazil stood at $3.34 billion.
600 made-in-Egypt products exported to Mercosur countries are fully exempt from taxes, as part of the free trade agreement signed between Egypt and the South America trade bloc.
eff8988a7e5b8ee77bf09cd315a018e3:
Egypt and Sudan have conducted quality military exercises, codenamed Eagles of the Nile, for the first time in their history to ensure that both armies remain well-prepared in the face of any regional dangers threatening their countries existence or jeopardising their national security.
Egypt has also reiterated its full support for Sudan’s national security in the face of any regional threats to Sudan’s territorial integrity and stability.
The media in both Egypt and Sudan are tasked with a major role, as both need to engage in a different discourse and make a clean sweep of any misperceptions that may regrettably have been instilled in the minds of average Sudanese and Egyptian people over the decades.
Egypt was never, even in the darkest moments of its relations with Sudan, the kind of bad neighbour that Al-Bashir’s media pretended.
Egypt’s goal to establish an industrial park in Sudan must, therefore, be given top priority, and all the Egyptian bodies concerned should not spare any efforts to realise this goal in the near future.
Thanks to connections between the two countries in terms of land and maritime transportation, it is now much easier to do business than it was, and there are more opportunities to further economic and trade relations between the two peoples.
The economic hardships facing Sudan today should not derail Egyptian entrepreneurs from starting joint projects in favour of the two peoples.
47321de6ec950dcd1fd733c8b5568099:
Sky Abu Dhabi, a real estate subsidiary of the UAE-based Emirati Diamond Group, will invest 15 billion Egyptian pounds ($950 million) in the Egyptian real estate market over the next two years.
Sky Abu Dhabi’s first project will be a 4 billion Egyptian pound investment in Egypt’s New Administrative Capital development.
The project extends over an area of 24 acres and includes the establishment of an integrated urban community consisting of around 1,000 housing units.
The company plans to spend 300 million Egyptian pounds on construction of the project this year, while aiming for sales of 1.5 billion Egyptian pounds in 2021.
The value of the land on which the project is based is estimated at 650 million Egyptian pounds due to the distinctive location.
80 percent of the project consists of residential units and the remaining 20 percent for commercial use.
Sky Abu Dhabi’s portfolio of projects includes 17 projects in the UAE market.
7a54b51214fc2210a202bc8b9399979c:
Pakistan is considering expansions in its densely populated large cities.
Pakistan is keen on benefiting from Egypt’s expertise in social housing.
Pakistan's PM, Imran Khan, praised advances related to development in Egypt, particularly in the New Administrative Capital.
Egypt and Pakistan are enhancing cooperation to build middle-class social housing and develop infrastructure in Pakistani cities and islands.
Egypt and Pakistan are strengthening trade cooperation and developing bilateral scientific and cultural cooperation.
a20e71b8098a35f2afd73cef4383e8c5:
Egypt has been elected to lead the United Nations (UN) Peacebuilding Commission for the first time, succeeding Canada.
Egypt's election to lead the commission's 15th session is a successful outcome of Egyptian diplomacy over a decade and a half in supporting the structure of the UN for peacebuilding since its establishment in 2005.
Egypt assumes the chairmanship in the wake of the successful conclusion of the third five-year comprehensive review process of the United Nations peacebuilding architecture.
Egypt remains fully committed as an African country to ensure the United Nations peacebuilding architecture remains engaged on the continent.
Egypt aims to further boost the commission's role in building back better, while ensuring sustained financing for peacebuilding as a high priority for the commission's ability and effectiveness.
Egypt is also very keen to continue to promote and expand the commission's partnerships with regional and subregional organisations and international financial institutions, with a view to ensure more efficiency and coherence in support of peacebuilding efforts.
6db576aafd64ba6898aa3abd31489e65:
The first phase of a national project to improve living conditions and create job opportunities for over 5,000 poor villages in Egypt was launched.
The first phase of the National Programme for the Development of Egyptian Villages will last until the end of the year and will target improving the quality of life in villages where 57 per cent of Egypt’s population resides.
The rate of poverty in these villages exceeds 55 per cent, and the rates of illiteracy and the percentage of households where women are the bread-winners are higher than in other villages and urban areas.
The villages included in the first phase are in 21 governorates across Egypt.
The project is designed to complement Egypt’s “Decent Life” programme to improve rural communities by ensuring better living conditions, reducing poverty, upgrading infrastructure and improving public services.
The programme also focuses on supporting small and medium enterprises [SMEs] in these villages, improving healthcare units, upgrading the efficiency of irrigation networks, enhancing agricultural and veterinary services and establishing advanced dairy collection centres.
The plan will include the relocation of public service offices in governorates and villages, and connecting them electronically to the related ministries in their new headquarters in the New Administrative Capital.
Egyptian companies will be tasked with providing the resources needed for the project.
The scheme is expected to provide several job opportunities for youth and revitalise the country’s economy.
7baed6da2684c43a9ad4dce2ba2209f7:
Egyptian President Abdel-Fattah El-Sisi inspected the Integrated Transport Centre project to reduce traffic congestion in Cairo.
The 300 feddan centre includes an international bus station, a transport terminal between governorates, a mall, an administrative complex, recreational areas and restaurants, a hotel and the workshops of Cairo Metro’s fourth line.
The project's location is in the centre of link axes connecting main roads nationwide, with its proximity to Cairo airport allowing for the facilitated mobility of travelers domestically and internationally.
The Suez Road has been upgraded to accommodate nine lanes in each direction, with the development of a road supporting the Ring Road with eight lanes in each direction and the construction of a new road to link the Ring Road, Suez Road and Mohamed Naguib Axis.
El-Sisi ordered an acceleration of implementation rates to reduce the traffic congestion on the main streets, ease the movement of citizens and reduce fuel consumption.
El-Sisi gave directives to ensure close coordination between all state bodies regarding renewing the facilities within the scope of these projects, which includes drainage systems and sanitation networks.
20c6c651af725283a12ba0f135cb7a6a:
GCC Secretary General Nayef Al-Hajraf met President Abdel-Fattah El-Sisi and hailed his role in protecting Arab national security.
GCC considers Egypt a main pillar for national security in the Arab region.
GCC Secretary General Nayef Al-Hajraf said the stability of Gulf states are connected to the security of Egypt, and the opposite is true.
GCC supports the Egyptian government in battling terrorism.
a2f7d67a885fdccfe0dfc1b34c814daa:
Egypt seeks to strengthen cooperation ties with Iraq through supporting development efforts in the country.
Egypt and Iraq reached an oil-for-reconstruction agreement, under which Egyptian companies will implement construction projects in Iraq in return for Iraq providing Egypt with certain quantities of oil.
Egypt, Iraq, and Jordan are targeting cementing cooperation ties in different fields, including oil pipeline power linkages ventures.
Egypt, Iraq, and Jordan met in a tripartite meeting to coordinate positions on issues of mutual concern and the Palestinian cause.
02d2765f2dad963e997705f50936b5e0:
The European Commission and the high representative announced the adoption of a new agenda for the Mediterranean region, including Egypt.
The agenda aims to boost the strategic partnership between the EU and the Mediterranean.
The agenda includes an economic and investment plan that targets boosting the long-term socio-economic recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic in the southern neighbourhood.
Under the new EU's Neighbourhood, Development and International Cooperation Instrument (NDICI), up to €7 billion for the period 2021 to 2027 will be allocated to its implementation, which can mobilise around €30 billion in private and public investments in the region over the next decade.
The new agenda focuses on five policy areas, including human development, good governance and the rule of law, resilience, prosperity, and digital transition.
The agenda also includes providing support to countries to address security challenges and find solutions to ongoing conflicts, in addition to addressing the challenges of forced displacement and irregular migration, and facilitating safe and legal pathways for migration and mobility.
The agenda concentrates on green transition as well as introducing an economic investment plan for the Southern Neighbours to ensure the quality of life for people in the region improves and economic recovery is realised.
The EU provided support to Egypt mainly through the European Neighbourhood Instrument with €756 million in the period from 2014 to 2020.
f6e137394c378c262b099598f344fb35:
Prime Minister Bisher Al Khasawneh conveyed a verbal message from King Abdullah to Egyptian President Abdel Fattah El Sisi, reaffirming the strong brotherly relations between the two countries.
The message highlighted views on issues of mutual interests and in service of Arab issues, foremost of which is the Palestinian cause.
The Egyptian president and the premier emphasized the deep-rooted, historical and strategic Jordanian-Egyptian ties, expressing keenness to further cooperation, notably in the economic and trade fields.
They also emphasized the necessity of bolstering the trilateral cooperation brought forth from the outcomes of the Amman-hosted tripartite summit between King Abdullah, President Sisi and Iraqi Prime Minister Mustafa Al Kadhimi.
Talks also went over expanding the trilateral cooperation to include more Arab nations for the best interests of these countries and their peoples.
Sisi and Khasawneh highlighted the two countries’ “unceasing efforts” towards serving Arab issues, foremost of which is the Palestinian cause, stressing the two countries’ firm stance on the necessity of the establishment of an independent Palestinian state on the June 4, 1967 lines, with East Jerusalem as its capital on the basis of the two-state solution, to achieve a fair and comprehensive peace in the region, as well as enhance regional security and stability.
c63302a288a7c8176dae057836fcbbf7:
Egypt's Prime Minister Mostafa Madbouly and his Jordanian counterpart, Bishr Al-Khasawneh, visited Downtown Cairo to inspect the ongoing development works at Tahrir square.
The development project will extend to sites in and around Tahrir square, including Omar Makram Mosque, the Mogamma government building, the Egyptian Museum, and the newly established Tahrir parking garage.
The project aims to restore the 150-year-old square to its former glory and create a civilised facade symbolising the spirit of ongoing development in the old capital.
The project will involve painting the facades of buildings, planting trees to create green spaces, and decorating the entire square with pure light LEDs to create a festive atmosphere.
The square is already home to a 17-metre obelisk that weighs 90 tons, dating back to the reign of the ancient Egyptian Pharaoh Ramses II, and four ram-headed sphinx statues from Luxor’s Karnak Temple.
The project is funded by the Ministry of Housing, Utilities, and Urban Communities in coordination with Cairo and the Ministry of Tourism and Antiquities.
31100741c6d097de56a0d375a7d358ff:
Saudi Arabia wants to promote bilateral strategic cooperation with Egypt on multiple levels.
Saudi Arabia's King Salman bin Abdul-Aziz sent a written message to Egyptian President Abdel-Fattah El-Sisi, emphasizing the deep historical ties between the two countries.
The message stressed the importance of continuing joint work and intensive coordination with Egypt on various regional and international issues.
Saudi Minister of State and Cabinet Member Essam bin Said conveyed the message to El-Sisi in Cairo.
El-Sisi reaffirmed the "special and strategic" relationship between Egypt and Saudi Arabia and its importance for regional stability.
El-Sisi highlighted the "delicate" circumstances and challenges facing Arab countries.
Both sides agreed to continue to reinforce bilateral cooperation and consultation in various fields to achieve the common interests of the Egyptian and Saudi peoples, as well as Arab solidarity bonds.
6d723f9cf811e44b313e9361be7549a4:
Egypt's Foreign Minister Sameh Shoukry congratulated Mariam Al-Sadiq Al-Mahdi, the new foreign minister in the new Sudanese cabinet, on assuming the post.
Shoukry affirmed to Al-Mahdi Egypt's keenness to enhance bilateral relations with Sudan and to intensify coordination to achieve foster constructive strategic cooperation tying the two countries.
Al-Mahdi expressed to Shoukry deep appreciation to Egypt and expressed her aspiration to continue joint work with the neighboring country to achieve stronger bilateral relations.
Al-Mahdi is the daughter of the late Sadiq Al-Mahdi, the leader of Al-Umma Party and two-time prime minister who passed away late last year.
Sudanese Prime Minister Abdalla Hamdok announced his new cabinet, which consists of 26 ministers, on Monday night.
Al-Mahdi also stressed to the Egyptian foreign minister that enhancing bilateral relations with Egypt during the coming period represents a priority to Sudan.
Shoukry urged in the phone call building on the strong bilateral relations between the two countries to move to further horizons of partnership and cooperation that serve the peoples of the two countries and enhance the historic official and popular ties between the two countries.
Shoukry also wished Sudan and the Sudanese people permanent progress, prosperity and development.
In recent years, Egypt and Sudan have voiced similar concerns in the ongoing dispute with Ethiopia over the Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam (GERD).
Both countries have repeatedly affirmed that a reaching a binding legal agreement on the filling and operation of the GERD between all three countries is the only way out of the current stalemate in negotiations.
8a4a147aa69b9c1e126bcb026183745f:
President Abdel-Fattah El-Sisi met with Jordanian Prime Minister Bisher Al-Khasawneh to discuss bilateral cooperation in energy, combating terrorism and extremist ideology.
Egypt, Jordan and Iraq are pushing for trilateral cooperation in economy, trade, energy and investment.
The three leaders have held three trilateral summits, with the latest in August 2020 in Amman.
A fourth trilateral summit is set to be held soon.
The officials agreed to maintain coordination to affirm the principle of a comprehensive political settlement for various disputes and issues in the region.
They discussed the developments of the peace process in the Middle East in light of the results of the last ministerial meeting of the Arab League.
The officials agreed to work on intensifying international efforts to settle the Palestinian crisis based on international legitimacy resolutions to resume peace negotiations.
Egypt, along with Jordan, France, and Germany, formed the quartet committee in February 2020 to revive the halted Israeli-Palestinian peace negotiations.
774cafdb67f25c87cb648e1b117683b4:
Egypt and Jordan agreed to hold meetings of the Joint Jordanian-Egyptian Higher Committee in Amman next month.
Jordanian Prime Minister Bisher Khasawneh delivered a verbal message from King Abdullah II to Egyptian President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi.
Sisi and Khasawneh stressed that Cairo and Amman will continue their efforts in serving Arab causes, foremost among which is the Palestinian issue.
Sisi and Khasawneh urged the need to strengthen trilateral cooperation, in light of the outcomes of the summit hosted by King Abdullah in Amman last August.
Khasawneh and Madbouly noted the joint Jordanian-Egyptian position on consultation and coordination on all issues of common interest to serve Arab issues, foremost of which is the Palestinian cause.
55f0c6f3e3a635dd51eef719a4b9db3a:
Pakistan's Foreign Minister Shah Mahmood Qureshi will start a three-day visit to Egypt on Tuesday.
The visit is expected to further strengthen and diversify Pakistan's bilateral ties with Egypt.
Pakistan and Egypt have similar perceptions on a range of regional and global issues.
More than 40 agreements have been signed between Pakistan and Egypt in diverse fields.
Bilateral cooperation is advanced through strong institutional mechanisms, including the Joint Ministerial Commission, Annual Bilateral Consultations, and Joint Business Council.
3e33fe100635ccc7a7d757fee6e66fd4:
Czech industrial real estate developer CTP Invest plans to invest $600 million in Egypt within the next five years.
CTP Invest will establish two business complexes in Cairo, each on a plot of 2 million square meters.
The complexes will create up to 14,000 direct new jobs.
The project will include a main logistical center, research and test centers, areas for entrepreneurship, small businesses and light industries, and a space dedicated to warehouses.
CTP Invest has more than 22 years of experience developing industrial business parks and currently owns projects in more than 100 locations, with a combined area of more than 6.3 million square meters, servicing around 700 clients across various sectors.
Prime Minister Mostafa Madbouly praised the company and directed the General Authority for Investment to conclude discussions and agree on a model going forward.
9a9439c55f803716e84df321b46b8dc4:
Foreign Minister Shah Mahmood Qureshi left for Egypt on Tuesday on a two-day official visit on the invitation of his Egyptian counterpart, Sameh Hassan Shoukry.
Qureshi will hold talks with Shoukry on the entire spectrum of bilateral relations.
Qureshi noted that Egypt is an important country of the Muslim Ummah and “is called the gateway to Africa”.
Promoting trade relations with Africa is a priority of the government.
Qureshi intends to visit Jamia Al Azhar during his visit to Egypt to “take advantage of their experiences in the field of education”.
Qureshi will also meet the business community in Egypt.
Last year, Ambassador of Egypt to Pakistan Tarek Mohamed Dahroug appreciated Pakistan’s efforts for regional peace and stability.
3e660f647f451d9897138e45fe2b27d9:
Pakistan's Foreign Minister Shah Mehmood Qureshi expressed Pakistan's keenness to reinvigorate traditional bilateral relationship with Egypt.
Qureshi called on President Abdel Fattah Al Sisi and reiterated Pakistan's desire to further strengthen and diversify bilateral ties.
Qureshi briefed the President on Pakistan's shifting focus from geopolitics to geoeconomics.
Qureshi stressed that the vision of ‘Naya Pakistan’ was predicated on economic connectivity and ensuring peace within and beyond Pakistan's borders.
Qureshi and President Sisi expressed satisfaction at the growing bilateral defence ties and discussed sharing their experience in countering terrorism and extremism.
Qureshi briefed the president on the situation in Pakistan's neighborhood, in particular Islamabad’s efforts to facilitate the Afghan Peace Process, the ongoing human rights violations in the Indian Illegally Occupied Jammu and Kashmir (IIOJK), and continued denial of the Kashmiri people’s legitimate right to self-determination.
President Sisi reciprocated the warm feelings of the Pakistani leadership and expressed hope that the visit of Foreign Minister Qureshi would pave the way for enhanced bilateral ties and dynamic multilateral cooperation.
President Sisi accepted the invitation of President Arif Alvi to visit Pakistan at the earliest opportunity.
b4ae522c696d28bb8dbb32c435d2cd6d:
Pakistan’s Foreign Minister Shah Mahmood Qureshi said Egypt and Pakistan are able to create a network to eradicate terrorism and intolerance.
Qureshi’s remarks came during a press conference held in Cairo with his Egyptian counterpart Sameh Shoukry.
Qureshi is on a three-day visit to Egypt, which started on Tuesday, upon invitation by Shoukry.
Qureshi thanked, during his speech, President Abdel-Fattah El-Sisi for his support to Pakistan and all developing countries.
Qureshi stressed that Egypt and Pakistan are able to establish a network to eradicate terrorism and intolerance.
ad2ccf0ce2b5a5116eda930d476e95b3:
Pakistan's Foreign Minister Makhdoom Shah Mehmood Qureshi visited Egypt for three days to discuss issues of common interest.
Pakistan and Egypt share close relations, common faith, culture and values, and face similar challenges in coronavirus and terrorism.
Egypt can help Pakistan enhance its presence in Africa.
Pakistan is considering expanding its densely populated cities and hoped to benefit from Egypt's expertise in social housing.
The crises in Libya and Syria were also high on the agenda.
Qureshi's visit included consultations with Egyptian officials and businessmen, as well as members of the Pakistani community in Egypt.
The visit also tackled the latest developments in the coronavirus pandemic and ways of combating terrorism.
Qureshi's visit followed an invitation from his Egyptian counterpart, Sameh Shoukri.
Cairo and Islamabad have jointly signed more than 40 agreements and work together closely in the multilateral arena.
e539409f8c8c12a9c9207f963f4a7820:

60332098bb983e3d8f6a1f41e5ca6e11:
The Biden administration and President Hassan Rouhani's government in Tehran both want to revive the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA), but their window is closing.
Rouhani's term will end in June when Iranians head to the polls, and the country's ruling clerics are all but certain to pave the way for a hardliner to become the next president.
As Iranian activity slows during its Nowruz new year holiday, there are no signs of an imminent breakthrough between Washington, D.C. and Tehran.
Rouhani has "fought tooth and nail" to keep the JCPOA alive despite domestic skepticism, but his options are almost exhausted.
With the end of the Rouhani era in sight, the momentum is with the conservatives.
A conservative president would ensure a smooth transition to the next supreme leader.
Among the candidates vying to be Khamenei's chosen man is Hossein Dehghan, a former IRGC air force brigadier general who served as Rouhani's defense minister.
It remains to be seen whether an IRGC or conservative candidate would—with approval from Khamenei—still pursue JCPOA revival.
A conservative president is unlikely to prove an easier negotiating partner for Biden.
For Iran hawks in Congress, the identity of Iran's next president is largely irrelevant.
Biden's public lack of progress on the JCPOA is concerning supporters of the accord.
Senator Chris Van Hollen (D-MD) said "the window for meaningful diplomatic engagement on Iran's nuclear activities is narrowing."
If Biden does miss the Rouhani window, Iran's next president will try to present the U.S. with a choice between "a regional war that's going to be very costly, or a new nuclear deal that is probably less strong than the JCPOA."
The head of the International Atomic Energy Agency, Rafael Grossi, has also acknowledged that the election will have a bearing on what role his inspectors play.
There is still hope for JCPOA progress in the coming months, even if both sides are sticking to their guns—at least publicly—and denying there has been any behind-the-scenes contact.
c9d45f6536dbfa6c2215f509aa5efca0:
A bipartisan group of 41 senators, led by Bob Menendez (D-N.J.) and Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.), have urged President Biden to use "diplomatic and economic tools" to address Iran's nuclear program.
The senators expressed concern over Iran's accelerated nuclear activity, including increased centrifuge research and production, and uranium enrichment up to 20 percent.
The Biden administration has stated that it will not lift sanctions imposed by the Trump administration until Iran returns to compliance with the JCPOA, which limits uranium enrichment to 3.67 percent.
Iran has rejected these terms and threatened to ban visits by international nuclear inspectors if concessions are not reached.
The bipartisan letter acknowledges differences between Democrats and Republicans on the JCPOA, but emphasizes unity in preventing an Iranian nuclear weapon and addressing Iran's other destabilizing activities.
The senators called for the use of diplomatic and economic tools, in collaboration with allies, to reach an agreement that prevents Iran from acquiring nuclear weapons and constrains its destabilizing activities.
They also raised concerns about attacks on U.S. personnel in Iraq by Iranian-backed militias and called for the release of American citizens held in Iran.
The senators emphasized the importance of consulting with key Middle East allies, such as Israel and Gulf nations, on a "path forward with Iran."
dfd68d7ff00da7982d9da6f02a399509:
43 U.S. senators, including those who opposed the 2015 nuclear agreement with Iran, appealed to President Joe Biden to work toward an international agreement that addresses issues beyond just Tehran's nuclear program.
The letter was led by Democratic Senator Bob Menendez and Republican Senator Lindsey Graham and signed by 41 other Democrats and Republicans.
The letter notes the "long-held view" from lawmakers and presidents from both parties that a nuclear-armed Iran would pose a grave threat to the natural security interests of the United States and its allies and partners.
The letter also says Iran poses a threat by exporting arms, supporting militants who target U.S. forces and via its ballistic and cruise missile programs.
The letter echoes an argument made for years by opponents of the nuclear agreement, who contended that any negotiation with Iran should address a wide range of concerns.
4d15bc71bc10c32f20737905aa142613: 43 US senators appealed to President Joe Biden to work toward an international agreement that addresses issues beyond just Tehran’s nuclear program.

Biden is now reportedly begging China to persuade Iran to give ground in negotiations, but China has not delivered anything in return and has instead given Iran a 25-year strategic partnership.
Biden is expected to suspend major U.S. sanctions in exchange for Iran's reduction of some enrichment activities, while fundamental flaws of the 2015 accord, such as Iran's ballistic missile research, will remain in place.

Congressman Bryan Steil (R-WI) has sent a letter to US Secretary of State Antony Blinken, requesting information on the United States’ involvement in facilitating a South Korean ransom payment to Iran.

The Obama administration made multiple secret deals with the Iranian regime, including allowing the Iranian regime to have access to US dollars by sidestepping sanctions and removing sanctions on several Iranian banks.
The Obama administration also agreed "in secret" to allow Iran to evade some restrictions in the last year of the nuclear agreement.
The Obama administration helped swiftly to lift all four rounds of UN sanctions against Iran and exempted Iran’s military sites from inspection by the International Atomic Energy Agency.
Iran never even signed the JCPOA deal.
Appeasement policies, secret deals and generous concessions to predatory regimes do not work and only empower and embolden leaders who have no intention of honoring agreements.

de08cbb3b07d449073c190830f945db1:
Iranians will go to the polls to pick a new president on 18 June.
Brig. Gen (ret.) Hossein Dehghan, the former defence minister-turned advisor to Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, is a possible contender.
Dehghan warned about the risks of a tactical conflict with the US escalating into a full-scale war.
Dehghan stressed that Tehran was “not after negotiations for the sake of negotiations”.
Dehghan added that Tehran would not rest until all forces from the US “terror state” were expelled from the Middle East.
Saeed Mohammad, a second brigadier general in the IRGC and former head of the IRGC-controlled Khatam al-Anbiya Construction Headquarter engineering firm, has also announced his intention to run.
Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, the populist conservative who served as president of Iran between 2005 and 2013, has yet to formally express plans to run in the 2021 elections.
Ahmadinejad has consistently ranked number one among prospective voters in a range of informal polling, pulling in up to 47 percent support.
20b2be224322b6748815a0631e234ec7:
Iran opened the door for candidacies for the upcoming presidential vote.
President Hassan Rouhani rejected the decision of the Guardian Council to study the candidates’ applications.
The Guardian Council specified that “all nominees must be between 40 and 70 years of age, hold at least a master’s degree or its equivalent, have experience of at least four years in managerial posts... and have no criminal record”.
The new terms come in implementation of a 2016 directive from Iran’s supreme leader Ali Khamenei for the council to clarify and “determine” the requirements.
The updated requirements are likely to exclude some well-known figures, such as Rouhani’s telecom minister, Mohammad Javad Azari Jahromi, who is 39, or the elite Revolutionary Guards’ Saeed Mohammad, whose rank is below major general.
The increasing number of Revolutionary Guard generals who have announced their candidacy or are likely to be intending to compete in the presidential race, have raised fears of the “militarization” of the political circle within the Iranian regime.
f72d47bc58f8c6835fff2b412c57ce03:
Conservative hardliner Ebrahim Raisi has registered as a candidate in Iran's presidential elections.
Raisi is favored to win the election, potentially complicating talks between President Joe Biden and Iran over its nuclear program.
Raisi has previously criticized the terms of the nuclear deal struck by incumbent Hassan Rouhani.
Raisi has the support of a wide range of conservatives and hardliners, who want to expand Iran's nuclear program.
Raisi's background as a hardline judge has raised concerns among reformists and rights groups.
A survey found that a majority (51 percent) of Iranians approved of the JCPOA, compared with only 44 percent in October 2020.
A clear majority (69 percent) of Iranians said that Iran should not get involved in nuclear talks until the U.S. returns to the JCPOA and fulfills its obligations.
Ali Larijani, a former adviser to the supreme leader, has also signed up for the election on June 18.
Over 59 million people are eligible to vote in the election, but there is expected to be a low turnout due to economic problems, international isolation, and a lack of basic freedoms.
c4e484da0c5f7669240d67f95f5a07f8:
Iran's presidential election will be held on June 18, with two main candidates being ultraconservative Ebrahim Raisi and moderate conservative Ali Larijani.
Larijani, a former parliament speaker and advisor to the supreme leader, submitted his candidacy on the final day of registration.
Raisi, the judiciary chief, announced his candidacy in a statement and appeared at the ministry to sign up.
Larijani criticized Raisi and other candidates with military backgrounds, stating that the economy should not be managed with "shouts and orders."
Larijani emphasized the importance of the economy and accused others of "promising paradise" in the country's current state.
Raisi said he aims to bring about change in the executive management of the country and fight against poverty, corruption, humiliation, and discrimination.
Larijani supports the 2015 nuclear deal and called for "smart relations with the West, strong and constructive relations with the East, and brotherly relations with our neighbours."
The Guardian Council will vet the candidates and publish a list of approved candidates by May 27.
2f1a2e3aa0c40306d59dcbb1ec236d7e:
Iran's election in June will determine the next president and possibly the successor of Supreme Leader Ali Khamenei.
Khamenei, who has been in power since 1989, is 81 years old and has several health problems.
The position of supreme leader is critical for the survival of the Islamic Republic and the continuation of Ayatollah Khomeini's revolutionary concept of Velayat-e Faqih.
The supreme leader has the final say on Iran's domestic and foreign policy and significant control over the legislative, executive and judicial systems.
The supreme leader also controls the IRGC, intelligence service, bonyad charitable trusts, and Setad organization.
The position of president can be a crucial stepping stone to succeeding the supreme leader.
Khamenei has increased his interventions in the presidential election and has even told the grandson of the Islamic Republic's founder, Hassan Khomeini, not to run.
The Guardian Council has significantly narrowed its terms for qualification for the presidential election, barring anyone older than 75 and younger than 40 from running.
The Guardian Council will also probably disqualify figures such as Mahmoud Ahmadinejad and anyone else the supreme leader disapproves of.
c875ebd76808807fa1aeb64174c5cfb4:
Iran’s Guardian Council began reviewing applications for the presidential race slated for June 18.
The Council refused to approve Expediency Council secretary and ex-commander of Revolutionary Guards General Mohsen Rezai.
The Council also refused to approve Gen. Saeed Muhammad, the executive director and second brigadier general in the Revolutionary Guard.
Iranian reformist Mohammed Ali Abtahi said the “tsunami” of filed presidential bids confused all equations, especially conservatives backing Ebrahim Raisi before Saeed Jalili entered the election scene.
Abtahi called for “upholding the constitution” in approving the candidacy of presidential runners from both political currents.
7c3cfb35488c814ae10843975a8b24f9:
Iran's Guardian Council approved seven candidates to run in June's presidential poll, including ultraconservative judiciary chief Ebrahim Raisi.
Former President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad was not approved to run for another term.
Former parliament speaker Ali Larijani was also barred from running.
Raisi has been linked to mass executions in 1988 at the end of Iran's war with Iraq.
Political analyst Ali Fathollah-Nejad said the upcoming elections would be "more of a farce" than previous polls.
bd107546c83e5f9f57b3d8e4f8013ad4:
Iran approved seven candidates for the presidential poll in June, with ultraconservatives dominating the list.
Moderate conservative Ali Larijani was disqualified, potentially boosting ultraconservative judiciary chief Ebrahim Raisi's chances of winning.
Ayatollah Sadegh Amoli Larijani, a senior official, criticized the Guardian Council's decisions as "indefensible."
Former president Mahmoud Ahmadinejad was also barred from running.
Reformists and conservatives criticized the list, with concerns about low voter turnout.
The Guardian Council's decision has been criticized by the public, with some saying it has turned the election into a formality.
The government denied reports that President Rouhani had asked Supreme Leader Khamenei to intervene.
The final list announcement comes amid ongoing nuclear talks in Vienna.
Larijani, a key supporter of the 2015 nuclear deal, accepted his disqualification.
Analysts believe Raisi is likely to win easily due to the disqualification of his main rivals.
8b4edc27b82bd0b0bbbd19acbab21519:
Supreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei urged Iranians to ignore calls to boycott next month’s presidential election.
Iranians are set to elect a successor to President Hassan Rouhani on June 18.
Iran’s candidate-vetting Guardian Council approved seven mainly ultraconservative hopefuls to run in the election and disqualified moderate conservative Ali Larijani and firebrand former president Mahmoud Ahmadinejad.
A record 57 percent of Iranians stayed away from legislative elections in February last year after thousands of candidates were disqualified.
The poll comes at a critical time for Iran amid talks with world powers aimed at reviving a nuclear deal.
4aa445ec4be711f18aceb1b34b95091a:
Iran's Supreme Leader Ali Khamenei supported the disqualification of leading moderate and conservative candidates for the June presidential election by the Guardian Council.
The Guardian Council approved seven out of 592 hopefuls including Iran's hardline judiciary chief Ebrahim Raisi.
Iranian President Hassan Rouhani asked the Supreme Leader to ensure greater "competition" in the elections.
Official opinion polls suggest turnout in the vote could be as low as 30%.
Khamenei called on Iranians to vote in the election, seen as a test of the legitimacy of the country's clerical rulers amid rising popular anger over economic hardship and restrictions on political freedoms.
a1a72cc70130e97ee06448a07985207a:
The Guardian Council has barred establishment candidate Ali Larijani from the Iranian presidential race.
Iranian supreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei defended the Guardian Council's decision to exclude moderates from the presidential election.
President Hassan Rouhani urged a rethink on the matter, emphasizing the importance of competition in elections.
Ali Larijani's brother Sadiq Larijani condemned the disqualification, alleging false information from the secret service.
Iran's judiciary chief Ebrahim Raisi's chances of winning the presidency have increased with Larijani's disqualification.
Analyst Ali Afshari believes Larijani's disqualification shows the intolerance of dissenting views within Iran's political system.
Larijani's disqualification is seen as a blow to hopes of reforming Iran's political system through elections.
Political scientist Ali Fathollah-Nedschad predicts a sham election with a hardline president, leading to increased influence for the Revolutionary Guards.
A survey suggests voter turnout could be as low as 30%.
e87034aaa915a2ef011c9d734750b545:
Iran's supreme leader, Ali Khamenei, has decided not to interfere with the Guardian Council's decision to keep the list of presidential candidates intact, guaranteeing the election of a conservative candidate.
Khamenei's decision is seen as a move to ensure that his successor will be a conservative.
The upcoming Iranian presidential elections, to be held on June 18th, will feature only conservative candidates, increasing alienation between the Iranian regime and the population.
Khamenei's decision may be related to concerns that another loss by Ibrahim Raisi, head of Iran's judiciary, would undermine the legitimacy of the conservatives and Khamenei himself.
Khamenei may also be concerned about his weakening abilities to withstand attempts by Rouhani and his men to get closer to the West.
Raisi's expected election and the weakening of the moderate camp will ensure that Iran continues its dogmatic policy towards Israel and could lead to an escalation of actions between the two countries.
The absence of checks and balances in the Iranian leadership could increase the chances of direct confrontation between Israel and Iran.
67f813d3f78e7df6d376795b67f68675:
Iran's presidential election system is fundamentally authoritarian, despite claims of democracy.
Supreme Leader Ali Khamenei appoints the IRGC's senior generals and the head of the judiciary, giving the military and judicial apparatuses an undemocratic character.
The Guardian Council, an unelected body appointed by Khamenei, disqualifies reform-minded candidates, women, and those perceived as disloyal to the state, limiting the people's choice in elections.
Khamenei insists Iran's elections are flawless, as he can select the candidates he wants to be president.
For the 2021 presidential election, the Guardian Council disqualified anyone who could have defeated Khamenei's pick, Ebrahim Raisi.
The regime is paving the way for Raisi to become the next president, as Khamenei sees him as his successor and the hard-liners seek to control all branches of government.
5b50b6c9d7ab77a9cb19b6bae9a3d653:
Iran’s Guardian Council will announce a review of candidates barred from this month’s presidential vote following the Supreme Leader’s intervention.
The Guardian Council spokesman Abbas Ali Kadkhodai said that the orders of the Supreme Leader are final and his ruling must be obeyed.
The Guardian Council acknowledged that it is not immune to error.
f62fd42bc5cde5854cd88afd74a0cc8e:
Iran's supreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei urged voters to turn out for this month's presidential election, warning that staying away would mean doing the work of the "enemies of Islam".
Iranians are set to elect a successor to President Hassan Rouhani on June 18 amid widespread discontent over a deep economic and social crisis.
The presidential election campaign kicked off on May 28, without fanfare and in an atmosphere of indifference, as many say the result is a foregone conclusion.
Iran's conservative-dominated Guardian Council approved seven candidates — five ultraconservative and two reformists — to run from a field of about 600 hopefuls.
Ultraconservative judiciary chief Ebrahim Raisi, who took 38 per cent of the vote in the 2017 presidential election, is widely seen as a favourite.
Rouhani, who is constitutionally barred from running for a third consecutive term, has warned of the risk of low turnout.
A record 57 per cent of Iranians stayed away from parliamentary elections in February last year in which thousands of candidates, many of them moderates and reformists, were barred from running.
The election comes at a critical time amid talks with world powers aimed at reviving a 2015 nuclear deal that offered sanctions relief in return for Iran's agreement to tight controls on its nuclear programme.
75d08094921a105577e5ff046ac68739:
Narges Mohammadi, a prominent Iranian human-rights activist, will boycott the upcoming presidential election, viewing it as a sham.
Iran's unelected supreme leader and Guardian Council have consolidated power, disqualifying all but seven candidates from running for president.
Mohammadi believes that elections offer no chance for Iran to transition to a true democracy, as previous strategies to create a rift in the system have reached a dead end.
Under President Hassan Rouhani, Iran has become more repressive, with Mohammadi facing prosecution, imprisonment, and a new trial for participating in a prison sit-in.
Mohammadi opposes the harsh secondary sanctions imposed by former President Donald Trump, believing they harm both the regime and the Iranian people.
Mohammadi supports individual sanctions on human-rights violators in Iran and calls for the international community to restrict their movements.
Mohammadi criticizes the current nuclear diplomacy with Iran, arguing that it should focus on human rights as well as the nuclear program.
Mohammadi believes that the upcoming presidential elections are propaganda to persuade outsiders of the clerical tyranny's democratic legitimacy.
25c8d1b77d56c51b0fda89090bf8ee49:
Iran's ex-parliament speaker Ali Larijani was barred from running in next week's presidential poll by the Guardian Council.
Larijani demanded an explanation for his disqualification, but the council's spokesman said the law does not mandate the body to explain its reasoning in public.
The council approved seven candidates, five of them ultraconservatives, to run in the election from a field of about 600 hopefuls.
In addition to Larijani, the council also barred first vice-president Eshaq Jahangiri and firebrand former president Mahmoud Ahmadinejad.
Sadegh Amoli Larijani, a former judiciary chief and brother to the ex-speaker, said "security bodies" were influencing the council's decisions through "false reports".
President Hassan Rouhani sent a letter to Khamenei asking him to intervene and ensure greater "competition" in the election.
The supreme leader urged voters to ignore boycott calls but turned a deaf ear to criticism of the vetting process.
A week later, however, he said some candidates had been treated "unjustly" as "they and their families were accused of false things", without giving names.
The Guardian Council said "false reports" had not influenced its decisions.
d11bb3ddbdbadda88cdc0b0138022105:
Iran held a final presidential debate Saturday, showcasing divisions within the country's politics.
Hardliners referred to those seeking ties to the West as "infiltrators."
Analysts and state-linked polling predict hardline judiciary chief Ebrahim Raisi as the front-runner in Friday's upcoming vote.
Former Central Bank chief Abdolnasser Hemmati criticized Raisi, linking him to former President Donald Trump and the collapse of Iran's nuclear deal.
Raisi dismissed Hemmati's criticism and vowed to return to the nuclear deal.
Hard-liner Alireza Zakani accused Hemmati of "huge treason" for sharing financial information with the International Monetary Fund.
Hardline former Revolutionary Guard chief Mohsen Rezaei described the Rouhani government as being run by "infiltrators."
Hemmati expressed willingness to speak with President Joe Biden and warned of increased sanctions if hardliners gain power.
State-linked Iranian Student Polling Agency estimated only 37% of Iranian adults watched the second debate.
ISPA polling predicts a turnout of around 41% of Iran's eligible voters, the lowest since the 1979 revolution.
Both Hemmati and Mohsen Mehralizadeh brought up mass protests that challenged the government, including the 2019 demonstrations over gasoline price rises.
Raisi stated that most of those arrested in the 2019 demonstrations have been pardoned, but provided no figures.
7a0cad4e41137b30a0b80e4e6e61628e:
Former Iranian parliament speaker Ali Larijani demanded an explanation from an election watchdog on why he was barred from running in next week's presidential vote.
The hardline Guardian Council approved just seven hopefuls to stand in Friday's poll and disqualified several prominent candidates, including Larijani and former president Mahmoud Ahmadinejad.
The decision to ban candidates boosted the prospects of hardline judiciary chief Ebrahim Raisi, an ally of Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei.
The approved candidates include former chief nuclear negotiator Saeed Jalili, a conservative; former Revolutionary Guards chief Mohsen Rezaei, a frequent presidential candidate; and current central bank governor Abdolnaser Hemmati, a low-profile moderate.
d4dd6672dc6cbef47e5290f37accd671:
Iran’s reformist candidate Abdolnasser Hemmati warned that a win for his ultraconservative rivals in the June 18 presidential election would result in the country facing more sanctions.
Iranians are to elect a successor to President Hassan Rouhani from seven candidates — five ultraconservatives and two reformists — approved to run by the election-vetting Guardian Council from a field of some 600 hopefuls.
Judiciary chief Ebrahim Raisi is widely tipped to win, after the Guardian Council disqualified many potential heavyweights, including moderate conservative Ali Larijani.
Rouhani took office vowing to seek better ties with the West and end Iran’s economic isolation over international sanctions.
Raisi insisted his administration would be “committed to the JCPOA (nuclear deal) as a contract and an obligation” as confirmed by Iran’s supreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei.
ed3445c1ec4f264c80bfed36ec568db6:
Ebrahim Raisi, a hardline candidate, won Iran's presidential election on June 18, 2021.
Raisi is a fierce loyalist to Iran's ruling clerics, including Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei.
Raisi has been accused of human rights abuses, including overseeing the execution of thousands of political prisoners in 1988.
Raisi has been sanctioned by the United States for human rights violations.
Raisi has promised to ease unemployment and support talks with world powers aimed at reviving the 2015 nuclear deal.
Raisi's election is expected to strengthen Khamenei's hand at home and could lead to more repression.
Raisi is seen as a potential successor to Khamenei as Supreme Leader.
3ab4b296f68a3cd4898c1605d5ffa1c9:
Iran's presidential election on Friday is likely to result in the victory of hard-line candidate Ebrahim Raisi, who is favored by Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei.
Raisi, who oversees Iran's judiciary, has been sanctioned by the U.S. for his involvement in human rights abuses, including executions and torture.
Raisi has threatened to assassinate former U.S. President Donald Trump for his role in the drone strike that killed Iranian General Qassem Soleimani.
Raisi has indicated that he would oversee Iran's return to the nuclear deal reached by former President Hassan Rouhani, which could have a positive impact on Iran's economy and its relationship with the West.
Iran's Gulf Arab neighbors have sought to improve ties with Iran in recent months, anticipating a return to the nuclear deal by the Biden administration.
Despite the potential for improved relations with other countries, Raisi faces challenges from within Iran, including widespread protests over the country's ailing economy.
7663b48b87b198137fc8631f5f90d3bf:
Iran's supreme leader urged voters to turn out in large numbers for the June 18 presidential election.
Two hardliners and one moderate quit the field of seven officially permitted candidates on Wednesday.
Judiciary chief Ebrahim Raisi is widely tipped as the favorite to succeed Hassan Rouhani.
Former nuclear negotiator Saeed Jalili and hardline lawmaker Alireza Zakani dropped out of the presidential race.
Moderate Mohsen Mehralizadeh also stood aside in a boost for Abdolnasser Hemmati.
Two other hardline candidates remain on the ballot, though they could step aside or back Raisi before Friday's vote.
Official opinion polls suggest turnout could be as low as 41%, significantly lower than in past elections.
The election comes as Iran is negotiating in Vienna with world powers to revive a 2015 deal under which it agreed to curbs on its nuclear program in return for the lifting of international sanctions.
A strong mandate for Raisi could strengthen Khamenei's hand at home, and affect the search for an eventual successor to the 82-year-old supreme leader.
8323a1f9e8273d3037ca24653ebc8329:
Ebrahim Raisi, Iran's current chief justice, is expected to win the presidential election.
Raisi is an ultraconservative politician who was involved in the execution of thousands of political prisoners in the late 1980s.
Raisi needs to secure an absolute majority to win the presidential election in the first round.
Polls suggest that only 23 million of the 59 million eligible voters plan to cast their votes.
If no candidate wins a clear majority on Friday, the two with the most votes will go head-to-head in a runoff a week later.
The election comes at a critical juncture for Iran, as the nation's economy is struggling to cope with the harsh US sanctions.
Raisi belongs to the ultraconservative camp that most deeply distrusts the United States.
Raisi has harshly criticized Rouhani since the nuclear deal began to unravel.
Raisi is an unknown figure for the international community, and his positions on important regional and global issues remain unclear.
Even though Raisi had sharply criticized the 2015 international nuclear deal, he stressed his intention to abide by the agreement during the election campaign.

Lebanon has been suffering a severe fuel shortage for more than two months due to the lack of sufficient foreign exchange to import it.
Nasrallah stressed the importance of: "Forming a government as soon as possible in order to start reaching solutions to the ongoing crises."
On 26 July, President Michel Aoun commissioned Najib Mikati to form a new government to succeed the caretaker government, which resigned six days after the explosion of the Beirut Port on 4 August, 2020.
23da1aff8ece1d9dfdfa8a64ca89ce7b:
Hezbollah will import fuel from Iran to address Lebanon's energy crisis.
Hezbollah's decision to import fuel from Iran is not politically motivated but aims to alleviate the suffering of the Lebanese people.
Hezbollah's decision to import fuel from Iran has broken the US siege on Lebanon and foiled its attempts to starve and humiliate the nation.
Hezbollah has long been helping the process of government formation in Lebanon.

The first vessel carrying Iranian fuel for Lebanon has already departed.
An oil tanker laden with fuel for the power grid has departed Iran, while another one is expected to depart on Saturday.
3b2ca4f093dda6a03dec6a937660902b:
The US cannot block Iran’s legitimate trade with other countries, including fuel shipments to Lebanon, says Iranian Foreign Ministry spokesman Saeed Khatibzadeh.
Hezbollah leader Sayyed Hassan Nasrallah announced that a ship carrying Iranian fuel was about to set sail for Lebanon, warning that the vessel and the tankers subsequently carrying Iranian fuel would be regarded as “Lebanese territory”.
Iran is ready to sell fuel to the Lebanese government and businessmen as long as there is demand, says Khatibzadeh.
The plan to send Iranian fuel to Lebanon is seen as a watershed in breaking US sanctions, which have targeted both countries.
Iran has never withheld its friendly hand from Saudi Arabia, says Khatibzadeh.
Baghdad has been hosting talks between Iran and Saudi Arabia in recent months on mending ties severed in 2016.
Iran’s new President Ebrahim Raeisi has made dialogue with neighbors one of his administration’s priorities.
Iraq hosted the Baghdad International Conference “For Cooperation and Participation” with the objective of easing tensions between Iran and Saudi Arabia.
f079344cfe1e6f3937f0ee73d66090d9:
An Iranian fuel tanker is about to reach Lebanon and has become near the entrance of the Suez Canal.
Hizbullah’s al-Manar TV quoted sources as saying that the tanker has become in the Mediterranean.
A second fuel tanker had left an Iranian port on Sunday for a yet to be identified destination.
A third tanker is being loaded with gasoline.

The vessels are not enough to resolve Lebanon’s fuel shortage problem.
Fuel shortages have forced businesses and government offices to close, even threatening blackouts at hospitals.
Hizbullah chief Sayyed Hassan Nasrallah said that "We will continue this process as long as Lebanon needs it."
Hizbullah chief Sayyed Hassan Nasrallah said that "The aim is to help all Lebanese, (not just) Hizbullah supporters or the Shiites."
Iran and its arch-enemy Israel have been engaged in a "shadow war" since February this year.
49bfea3a75e46c846755eaf89d196df2:
Iran's first fuel tanker is en route to Lebanon to alleviate fuel shortages.
A second Iranian fuel tanker has departed port and is underway to Lebanon.
Hezbollah is on alert in case Israel interferes with the Iranian fuel tankers.
Hezbollah chief Sayyed Hassan Nasrallah has warned the US and Israel that the Iranian fuel tankers will be considered "Lebanese territory."

Fuel shortages in Lebanon have caused businesses and government offices to close, threatening blackouts at hospitals and halting transportation and other vital sectors.
Hezbollah leader Nasrallah has announced that a deal has been reached with Tehran to import a third fuel-loaded tanker to Lebanon.
